story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in the Philippines, there was a kind and curious little girl named Maya. Maya loved to explore the world around her and learn new things every day. She would often ask her mother questions about the stars, the trees, and the animals that lived in the forest.

One day, Maya's mother told her a bedtime story about a magical creature that lived in the forest called the "Nuno sa Punso." The Nuno sa Punso was a tiny old man who lived inside ant hills and protected the creatures of the forest.

Maya was fascinated by the story and begged her mother to take her to the forest to see if she could find the Nuno sa Punso. Her mother warned her that the Nuno sa Punso was a shy creature and that she must be very quiet and respectful if she wanted to see him.

The next day, Maya and her mother set off into the forest, looking for the Nuno sa Punso. They walked quietly through the trees, listening for any signs of the magical creature. Suddenly, Maya spotted a tiny ant hill and knelt down to get a closer look.

To her surprise, she saw a tiny old man peeking out from inside the ant hill. He was no bigger than her thumb and had a long white beard that reached down to his waist. Maya held her breath and watched as the Nuno sa Punso emerged from his home.

He looked up at Maya and smiled, revealing a set of tiny, sharp teeth. "Hello, little one," he said in a soft, raspy voice. "What brings you to my home?"

Maya introduced herself and asked if she could ask him some questions. The Nuno sa Punso agreed and told her all about the creatures of the forest and the magic that lived within it. Maya listened with wide eyes and a smile on her face.

Before they left, the Nuno sa Punso gave Maya a small seed and told her to plant it in her backyard. "This is a very special seed," he said. "It will grow into a tree that will bring happiness and good fortune to your family."

Maya thanked the Nuno sa Punso and promised to take good care of the seed. She and her mother returned home, and Maya planted the seed in her backyard. Sure enough, a beautiful tree grew, and Maya's family was blessed with happiness and good fortune for many years to come.

From then on, Maya always remembered the lessons she learned from the Nuno sa Punso - to be kind, curious, and respectful to all creatures, big and small. And every night, before she went to bed, she would look up at the stars and think of the magical creature who lived in the forest, protecting the creatures and sharing his wisdom with those who were lucky enough to find him.

The end.

Good night, Maya. I hope you have sweet dreams and always remember to be curious and kind.
